posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: Same as the FRC Pet Peeves and Programming Pet Peeves, but for CAD this time.

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

posts.cooked:
Not naming parts

Not naming mates

Not using folders

Not using replicate

The first four off my head
When people do CAD in the main robot document instead of individual sub-documents. Last year, I had someone add a folder named “Bumper Shenanigans” to our main, public robot document…

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: Not adding a material to parts.

posts.name: Bailey
posts.cooked: under-constrained sketches

posts.name: Eric Chinoy
posts.cooked: Me when I do everything mentioned here (sorry future me)

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked:
I’m curious how do teams keep things organized between sub documents well when working on multiple subassemblies

Do you instantly have a sketchup in the main and import into it, while having all the others reference it?

bkahl:

under-constrained sketches

You’re right, I need to have 17 over constrains per part. If the sketch isn’t red I’m doing it wrong

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: We use a master document, with a master sketch that has our core geometry, and the assemblies and part studios in each of the subassembly documents reference that. Then, each subassembly is combined into a single assembly in that same master document.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: So when you change a core design it’s done on the master. Then the subassemblies are auto updated to reflect it and finite changes based off that?

Our process is pretty much just what frcdesign.org outlines in their learning course.

I don’t really take issue with doing all your CAD in one document instead of multiple, my “pet peeve” is mostly just when people break the established organizational structure.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: We did that last year, I’ve done it with smaller assemblies and what not with no issue. But it definitely had its headaches, and I’m looking to moving towards top down and other ways to improve our models. I saw frc design talk about it and need to do more on relearning a new style.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: Yeah. When we adjust things like scoring geometry that are in the master sketch, we make the changes there and it updates to the other documents. When we make smaller changes, those are in the sub assemblies, such as where we put screw holes, and we change them in the sub assemblies and those get updated to the master assembly.

posts.name: diego
posts.cooked: individual part studios for each part/assembly…

As a solidworks team alum, solidworks filesharing CacheCAD is what we use now which isn’t bad but seeing onshape filesharing makes me feel like this:

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: Last off-season when training rookies, we literally told them that if they ever needed an example of what NOT to do when CADing the robot, look at that CAD.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Having multiples of the same bracket/angle piece in the assembly but each part is a different model.
